utterances: Great.
Okay.
Well, thanks for taking the time to talk with us, and have a great Christmas.
No problem.
Thanks.
You too.
We got an e-mail here from Suzanne(ph) at an undisclosed restaurant.
She says I am working today, but don't feel too sorry for me.
The restaurant I work for is charging $95 for dinner plus tax and gratuity.
And we're booked solid.
Happy holidays, Suzanne at an undisclosed restaurant.
We also have an e-mail from Andrew(ph) in Independence, Kentucky.
He writes: I'm a police officer in Northern Kentucky.

While working Christmas Day is not my first choice of activities, I was pleasantly surprised earlier today when a man approached my police car while I was parked in front of his house and invited me into his home to meet his family.
They offered me a drink and food and we carried on a great conversation.
I enjoy any opportunity I have to meet and get to know the residents in the area I serve, but I'm especially grateful for the invitation earlier today.
The Christmas spirit is certainly alive in northern Kentucky.
We're glad to hear it.
Let's take another caller.
This is Spencer(ph) in Cleveland, Ohio.
Hi, Spencer.
Hi.
How are you?
Fine.
How are you spending this Christmas Day?
Well, it started out fine.
Well, it started last night actually.
I'm a carpenter and I remodel homes and maintain some properties for some friends, and got a call last night.
I was in my Christmas dodge, on my way to a Christmas party and had a toilet leak.
Oh, dear.
So I went and fiddled with the toilet, thought I fixed it about this morning, had a nice morning and I had to go back, something else broke, so I'mâ€¦
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's just (unintelligible) actually broken toilet I have been working on.
Not exactly the way you had planned to spend your Christmas, huh?
Absolutely not.
I suppose I'd brighten someone else's.
I hope so.
Well, thanks for your call.
I suppose this will certainly be a memorable Christmas for you.
Absolutely.
Merry Christmas.
And to you.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.
Well, our next guest is Jeff Monroe.
He is head athletic trainer for Michigan State University football.
He joins us from his hotel room in Orlando, Florida.
Jeff, thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
So your final game with the season is in two days.
Shouldn't you be at practice right now?
Thank you so much.
Yeah, 22 years.
This is our 13th bowl game that I've been to and been away at Christmas every one of them.
And do you have any special traditions surrounding that fact that you may be in a different city Christmas every year?

Well, when the kids are growing up, we would have a little arrangement of ornaments, et cetera, in the room and we would have some small presents that we would bring along that they would get to open and have fun with.
And then when they came home or before we left, we would do a bigger Christmas.
So you got to take your kids with you every Christmas?
Yeah.
That was the great part.
Elizabeth(ph) and Missy(ph) are about three years apart and they started when they're about 8 and 11.
And they just knew every hotel layout every time we got in.
If we needed anything, we ask where this was or where that was and they knew it.
We went to the Rose Bowl with them and went to the Citrus Bowl and other major bowl games down the line, Gator Bowl, et cetera.
They knew all the ins and outs of all the hotels and resorts.
And it was fun to have them run around and do our jobs.
Well, that sounds like a great Christmas tradition for the family.
Do you have any special things that you do with the team on Christmas as opposed from any other days?
Do you go a little easier on them for Christmas Day?
Yes, that's a good question.
We were scheduled for a pretty good practice, today and yesterday.
Coach in the meeting, coach Antonio, in his first year, decided, well, maybe we should back them off a little bit today and let them have some fun.
So last night, we had a team official party dinner; everybody received a gift from the bowl committee, a nice watch.

And today, they had a big Christmas breakfast and now, we're having the pictures day and they're going to do walk throughs and do special teams and special situations for about an hour, so it's going to be a very light practice.
Well, we'll let you get back to your team's practice.
But thanks a lot for taking time out of your Christmas Day to talk with us.
Thank you, sir.
Jeff Monroe is head athletic trainer from Michigan State University football, and he joined us from his hotel room in Orlando.
We've got an e-mail here from Bear(ph) in Spokane, Washington.
He writes: Kudos to all the Zamboni drivers at the family ice rinks across the country.
We're open before and after dinner, so people have something to do.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Let's take another caller.
This is Mama Elf(ph) in Miami, Florida.
That's right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I have the best job in the world.
What job is that?
Well, I am the personal assistant to the real Santa Claus.
Really?
Yes.
And what does your job entail today?
Well, my job today - today, Santa Claus is really tired from last night, so he's been home kind of resting a little bit.
And believe it or not, he came all the way from the North Pole to be in Miami, Florida for months.

And right now, I'm going to a country club to do storytelling for the children and tell them all about Santa Claus, and then I'm going to go pick up Santa Claus and we're going to do some home visits.
Home visits to ill or elderly people?
No.

We're going to children's homes, to private homes and we're going to visit them and bring them some gifts and let them take pictures with Santa Claus and tell them little stories about the North Pole and the elves and everything that we do.
Well, I hate to sound skeptical, but, you know, there are a lot of impostors out there.
